goal.en:
LIMITED TO ENGLISH FRESHMEN. 
This course was specifically designed for English 
Freshmen. If you are not a first-year student majoring in English, you will not be allowed to enroll.

Overview: Literature, History and Philosophy seeks to 
provide students with conceptual tools for examining 
questions, methodological puzzles, and views around the 
transformative experience generated by 
three modes of inquiry: (i) Fiction; (ii) History and 
(iii) Philosophy.

outline.en:
ALL COURSE CONTENT WILL BE PROVIDED IN
ENGLISH.
For the course content, we will examine the following
problems: (1) Why should we care about the
humanities? (2) What makes a literary text?
(3) What does history consist of? What does it
mean to know, represent, and explain the “past”?
(4) What is the feasibility of philosophy?

textbook.en:
Main references:

* Koselleck, Reinhart, 2002, The Practice of Conceptual 
History: Timing History, Spacing Concepts, Stanford 
University Press. 

* Kroon, Fred ＆ Alberto Voltolini, 2019, “Fiction,” In 
Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. 

* John, Eileen ＆ Dominic McIver Lopes, 2004, The 
Philosophy of Literature: Contemporary and Classic 
Readings. An Anthology, Wiley-Blackwell.  

* Libraries Michigan State University, Public Philosophy 
Journal [https://pubhub.lib.msu.edu/projects/project-collection/public_philosophy_journal]

* Little, Daniel, 2010, New Contributions to the Philosophy of History, Springer Science. 

* Nussbaum, Martha C., 2016, Not for Profit: Why 
Democracy Needs the Humanities, Princeton University 
Press. 

* Paul, L.A., 2016, Transformative Experience, Oxford 
University Press. 

* Walton, Kendall, 2008, Marvelous Images: On Values 
and the Arts, Oxford University Press. 

Course handouts and references will be ready to be 
photocopied the first week of classes.

gradMethod.en:
ATTENDING THE FIRST CLASS IS 
MANDATORY.

WORK FOR THE COURSE: 
Weekly Attendance: 20％ 
[With more than two absences, 
the student will automatically fail the course. Please, 
bear this in mind.]
Weekly Classroom Participation: 20％ 
Midterm Presentation: 30％
Final Presentation: 30％
